section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld
section-block.rac_book_summary: A little cloud doesn’t mind being small. Other clouds call her cute names, and she always finds a place to watch the fireworks. But she wants to do important things, like help kids get a snow day! Cloudette finds a way to do important things despite her small size.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk to children about clouds. Discuss what clouds do. What do clouds look like? Are some dark? What usually happens when the clouds are very dark?
(Tune: “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star”) Look outside now, can you say What the weather is today? Is there sunshine, is there rain, Is wind blowing down the lane?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Cloudette. It is written and illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld.
Scout likes reading books about the weather. He thinks this narrative about a little cloud named Cloudette is really fun.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
What could Cloudette do that the bigger clouds couldn’t do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to help choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How was Cloudette different from the other clouds? Being small had advantages for her. What does that mean? Do you think there are advantages to being in PreK?
What tight spaces could Cloudette sneak through?
Who is she hiding from in this picture?
One night, Cloudette lay awake wondering about something.
Did you ever lie awake wondering about something? What was Cloudette wondering about?
What did Cloudette hear? Can you make that sound? What animal made that sound?
What did Cloudette see when she looked down? What is a puddle? What was supposed to be there?
As soon as Cloudette made it rain, what happened? How many frogs do you see in this picture? Why did the frogs return to the pond?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What could Cloudette do that the bigger clouds couldn’t do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to help pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: She could sneak through tight spaces.
She could hide in small places.
She could find a good spot to watch the fireworks.

section.rac_body-text: As children watch and listen, write and read aloud short sentences about different kinds of weather.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Cloudette could sneak through tight sp_____ (spaces).
Cloudette could sneak through tight spaces.
What were some other advantages of being little?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: One of the milestones in children’s social-emotional development at this age is their increasing awareness of self as distinct from others. Cloudette’s concerns about her size and her coming to terms with what she is capable of compared to the other clouds will engage children in interesting discussions about differences.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make Plans
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss the importance of making a plan and taking steps toward a goal with children. Have they ever really wanted to do something? What did they do to make it happen? Ask: What was your plan? What was your first step? What did you do after that? Did it help you to have a plan? What can you plan to do today? How will you make that plan come true?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Cloudette by Tom Lichtenheld. We will listen for how Cloudette made plans to do something important.
Clifford likes to think of things he wants to do. Then he has to figure out the steps to take to get there. He enjoys reading about how Cloudette made a plan to do something important.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book and talk about some pages in the story to notice the make plans Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to help pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Sometimes, the big clouds would plan important things.
What did they plan to do? (MB)
Why was Cloudette feeling blue?
What important things had she tried to do? What happened?
What did Cloudette ask the frog? What did the frog reply that gave Cloudette an idea? What idea was she getting? (MB)
What was Cloudette’s plan? How did she make it happen? (MB)
Do you think Cloudette has ideas for other plans? What do you think her new plans are? How do you feel when you’re doing something important? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Ask children if they have ever looked at clouds and thought that they looked like something else—a lion, a bird, a dragon. Invite children to draw different types of clouds that might look like something else. Have them explain their drawings to their classmates.

Then, have children draw different types of clouds—the puffy white clouds we see when the weather is nice, and the dark clouds that we see when it’s going to rain. Or have children use cotton balls, glue, and paper to make three-dimensional sculptures of the different types of clouds.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about the weather and how rain helps people and other living things.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: It’s important from a very early age to help children set goals and figure out how to meet them. This can help them develop a positive, can-do attitude for the rest of their lives. Encourage even the youngest children to think of a small goal they want to accomplish and figure out the steps they need to take to achieve it. (Parents.com/Goal setting)

section-block.rac_body-text: Cloudette felt that she didn’t belong. Ask children if they have ever felt that way. What did they do?
Have children move as if they are in different kinds of weather: rainy, windy, snowy, hot, cold. What movements suit each weather condition?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit Cloudette. It was written and illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld.
Scout the Squirrel can make a connection to how Cloudette felt. Sometimes he feels as if he doesn’t belong. He wants to read the book again to see how Cloudette solved her problem.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What did Cloudette want to do that the bigger clouds could do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where did Cloudette sleep at night that made her feel cozy?
How will the bigger clouds make some mighty rivers flow? Do you think they will cause a storm?
What happens to rivers when there is too much rain? Too little?
How are the bigger clouds helping the farmers? Why is there a rainbow?
What are some of the important things that Cloudette wanted to do? What is a brook? How could Cloudette make a brook babble or a waterfall fall?
Who did Cloudette try to help? Why didn’t they need her help? Did she feel frustrated? What do you do when you’re frustrated that you can’t do something?
Did you make any connections to the story we read today? Did you ever want to do something important? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What did Cloudette want to do that the bigger clouds could do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to help choose 2–3 children to share:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: She wanted to make a waterfall.
She wanted to make a garden grow.
She wanted to make it snow.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how clouds affect the weather.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did she want to make grow?
She wanted to make a garden gr_____. (grow)
She wanted to make a garden grow.
Why did Cloudette want to make it snow?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: A child’s capacity for empathy begins very early in life. Empathic children are far more likely to engage in positive social behaviors. Helping kids make connections to Cloudette’s experiences with the other clouds and with her own feelings will help to get them on the path to empathizing with their peers, now and for years to come.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in discussing all they have learned this week about clouds and weather. What new information did they learn? What questions do they still have?
Have the class sing:Rain, rain, go away! Come again another day. Our friend [child’s name] wants to play. Go around the circle, using children’s names.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read What’s the Weather? It is an informational text in the form of a poster about types of weather.
Scout loves to read about what children do in different weather.
Both Cloudette and What’s the Weather? are about all kinds of weather. Let’s see if we can find connections between the two.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question: How can weather affect us?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the poster, then use the following prompts to discuss it.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Point to the boy dressed for a rainy day. How does he protect himself from the rain? What do you do on rainy days?
What do rain clouds look like? How are the big clouds helping people?
How is the boy dressed for the cold? What can you do on a snowy day? What can you wear to protect yourself?
Do you like windy days?
Let’s make a noise like leaves in the wind and make believe that we’re trees, with our branches swaying in the wind.
Can a sunny day have clouds? How do you protect yourself on a sunny day?

section.rac_body-text: Have children observe and record the weather. Work together to create symbols for sunny, cloudy, rainy, and so on. After making the symbols, have children take turns being the daily weather person, placing the correct symbol(s) on the calendar. If the weather changes during the day, ask a child to change the symbol(s).
Provide a writing prompt about weather and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Content-area explorations can provide fun and exciting opportunities for multilingual learners to make discoveries and use their language skills. Make sure to review all of the weather vocabulary so that all children have a common understanding of the terms.

section-block.rac_body-text: Start Circle Time by having children think about the type of weather they learned about this week, and the type of weather that they like most. Ask individual children to act out being outdoors in their favorite weather, while the others guess which type of weather their classmates are acting out.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Cloudette by Tom Lichtenheld.

This book is a narrative. A narrative is a story that the author made up. Cloudette is a made-up story, but we still learn about how real clouds help real animals, plants, and people. Scout loves stories about weather!

This week we read all about Cloudette and how the little cloud found a way to do something important. As we read the book one more time, there is a question I want you to think about. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What important thing did Cloudette do?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What kind of weather is this? How do you know this is a storm? What do you think it means that the rain came down like cats and dogs?
What does it mean that no one seemed eager to know Cloudette? If you were eager to know her, how would you show it? What would you say?
Let’s act out how Cloudette made herself rain. What did she do first? Let’s hold our breath for two seconds. One. Two. Let’s shake our bodies. Let’s make a rumbling sound. What’s the rumbling sound?
What happened to the puddle? Why was the pond perfect?
Why was Cloudette exhausted? Show me how you look when you are exhausted!
Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
What important thing did Cloudette do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: She turned the puddle into a perfect pond.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how weather can affect us and to share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did Cloudette make it rain or snow?
What can happen if it rains too much?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children love to explore the natural world around them. Science learning always begins with curiosity. The questions that come up can create a sense of discovery that will benefit children in all their learning. Encourage children to think about the science content underlying this week and how it connects to their own experiences.
